required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: High-Flow Nasal Oxygenation Versus Standard Oxygenation in Gastrointestinal Endoscopy With Sedation.
clinical_study.official_title: High-Flow Nasal Oxygenation Versus Standard Oxygenation in Gastrointestinal Endoscopy With Sedation. A Prospective Multicenter Randomized Study

brief_summary.textblock: This study is a randomized controlled trial comparing high-flow nasal oxygen therapy (HFNO) versus standard oxygen therapy (nasal prongs, nasopharyngeal catheter or standard face mask) during gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy with sedation to reduce the incidence of hypoxia.

detailed_description.textblock:
Hypoxemia is the most common complication during a gastrointestinal endoscopy with sedation. Oxygenation is usually applied during the procedure to prevent the occurrence of desaturation. Conventional oxygen is typically administered by conventional nasal cannula, by nasopharyngeal catheter or by a facemask with mild flow of oxygen. The flow of standard oxygen is limited to 15L/min.
High-flow nasal cannula oxygenation is a new method of humidified and heated oxygenation with a higher flow rates (up to 70L/min).
The primary outcome will be the incidence of hypoxia defined by pulsed saturation with oxygen (SpO2) ≤92%. The investigator's hypothesis is that high-flow nasal oxygen therapy will decrease the frequency of hypoxemia during gastrointestinal endoscopy under sedation.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of hypoxia in the recovery room
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Length of stay in the recovery room, an expected average of 2 hours

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of apnea during the procedure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Breath rate ≤6/min

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: SpO2 ≤ 92% for ≥60 s

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: SpO2 ≤ 90% and SpO2 ≤85%

secondary_outcome.measure: Modification of oxygenation during the procedure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Increase of oxygen flow in conventional group or FiO2 in the interventional group to maintain an adequate oxygenation

secondary_outcome.measure: The need of intervention by the anesthesia team
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Need of airway manipulation, use of noninvasive ventilation or mechanical invasive ventilation

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Absolute changes in SpO2

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Absolute changes in respiratory rate, in cycles/minutes

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Absolute changes in heart rate, in bpm

secondary_outcome.measure: Temporal course of arterial blood pressure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Absolute changes arterial blood pressure, in mmHg

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Heart rate < 50 bpm

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of need for mechanical respiratory support
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: noninvasive ventilation, or ventilation through a laryngeal mask, or tracheal intubation

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Number of patients in whom the endoscopic procedure has to be stopped and postponed

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: From insertion of the fiberoptic endoscope to its withdrawal, in minutes

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Duration of GI endoscopy procedure under sedation, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: From anaesthesia induction to the awakening of the patient, in minutes

secondary_outcome.measure: Length of stay in the recovery room
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Length of stay in the recovery room, an expected average of 2 hours
secondary_outcome.description: From admission at to discharge from the recovery room, in minutes

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 24 hours
secondary_outcome.description: percentage of ambulatory patients who needed to be hospitalised after the procedure

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 24 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Percentage of patients experiencing at least one serious adverse event

arm_group.description: Participants in the experimental group will receive high-flow nasal oxygen therapy (HFNO) during gastrointestinal endoscopy under sedation (with a flow at 70L/min and oxygen inspired fraction (FiO2) 50%) through a dedicated system, the THRIVETM (Fisher&Paykel, New-Zealand)

Participants in the current standard of care will receive standard oxygenation by nasal prongs (with a flow at 6L/min) or naropharyngeal catheter (with a flow at 5L/min) or standard face mask (with a flow at 6L/min)

intervention.description: usual care + High-flow nasal oxygenation (HFNO) therapy during GI endoscopy under sedation (with a flow at 70L/min and FiO2 50%) through a dedicated system, the THRIVETM (Fisher&Paykel, New-Zealand)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age greater than or equal to 18 years
- Having GI endoscopy expected under sedation
- At risk of hypoxia defined by (one of the item): an underlying cardiac disease ; an underlying respiratory disease ; age greater than or equal to 60 years ; ASA II, III or ASA IV ; with an body mass index greater or equal to 30 (kg/m²); with sleep apnea syndrome diagnosed or suspected with a STOP-BANG score ≥ 3
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age below 18
- Emergency GI endoscopy
- Need of intubation for the procedure
- Patient with chronic oxygen treatment
- Patients with tracheostomy
- Pregnancy, breastfeeding
- Not affiliated to French social security

Qadeer MA, Rocio Lopez A, Dumot JA, Vargo JJ. Risk factors for hypoxemia during ambulatory gastrointestinal endoscopy in ASA I-II patients. Dig Dis Sci. 2009 May;54(5):1035-40. doi: 10.1007/s10620-008-0452-2. Epub 2008 Nov 12.

Cohen LB, Wecsler JS, Gaetano JN, Benson AA, Miller KM, Durkalski V, Aisenberg J. Endoscopic sedation in the United States: results from a nationwide survey. Am J Gastroenterol. 2006 May;101(5):967-74.
Griffin SM, Chung SC, Leung JW, Li AK. Effect of intranasal oxygen on hypoxia and tachycardia during endoscopic cholangiopancreatography. BMJ. 1990 Jan 13;300(6717):83-4.
